The exhaust air is not used in reverse thrust, it is pushed to the back of the aircraft. The amount of air that brakes the aircraft is the one that usually passes through the turbine bypass section.
@PDuarte: That's just an implementation detail. It doesn't negate the fact that *all air* coming out of the engine has more energy (momentum) than it had going in.
@PDuarte and more thrust comes from the bypass air than from the exhaust. so diverting all bypass will result in a netto negative forwards thrust.
There is no "why." "Why" is for philosophy. "How" is for science. The answer will show **how** the net force is in opposition to the aircraft's motion.

This is not 100% true -- take a look at helicopters, where you can kill the engine and the back-force on the rotors will actually bring you to a soft landing. The difference is that the total blade area in a jet turbine engine is pretty small compared with helicopter blade area.

@CarlWitthoft: That isn't at all relevant here. Auto-rotation in a helicopter relies on the the fact that a significant amount of kinectic energy is "stored" in the rotating mass of the blades themselves, and there's a significant amount of potential energy in the mass of the helicopter due to its altitude. You use the potential energy to keep the blades turning as you descend at a controlled rate, and then use the kinectic energy to produce extra lift at the end and achieve a soft landing. In terms of the aerodynamics, it's no different from landing a fixed-wing glider.
Dave, I think the principle is the same so long as the fixed-wing craft is moving relative to the local atmosphere. I fully agree that the effect is tiny due to the size of the turbine blades.
@CarlWitthoft: No, it's completely different. Thrust reversal does not rely on stored energy (gravity or kinectic) at all.
@CarlWitthoft: It's a valid comment, but the edit was inappropriate. We all understand the distinction that the OP is making.
Dave, I didn't mean to imply that. I was suggesting there was an *additional* braking force due to autorotation. Sorry for the mixup.

There is an independent maximum flow through both of the locations where choking can occur. The actual flow through the system will be determined by the smaller maximum. The choked location that could have a greater flow will "adjust" to whatever that lower flow is. Remember that the pressure regulator presents a variable sized orifice until it's fully open which provides one means for the system to adjust. Since you're using a regulator to ensure the pressure drop is critical, I suspect that the area of the regulator adjusts so that the flow through it and out of the system match.

For fixed orifice sizes, you will see the adjustment occur with pressure. Since these are critical pressure drops, this means you will see more or less pressure lost to turbulence. In this case, it's also possible that at the lower flow rate, the pressure drop through one of the restrictions is low enough to switch from critical to non-critical flow. You have to consider how the flow and pressure profile in the system develop once the maximum flow through the system has been determined.

You will likely not reach the wet bulb temperature but may get close depending on how well you distribute the water. Wet bulb is measured by wetting a cloth and swinging it in the air. The resulting temperature of the wet cloth is the wet bulb temperature. It relies on reaching full saturation in the area of the measurement. Given that, your best bet is to increase the amount of evaporation and heat transfer. Mist will work the best. Drip tube will barely work unless the flow rate is so great to remove heat by conducting it away from the roof.

_"...assuming it was uniform at the inlet."_ Are you assuming the flow _IS_ (somehow?) uniform at the inlet, or it was _modeled_ as uniform at the inlet? Your fluid is incompressible. Anywhere you look, the center of the pipe will be going faster than the average flow, and flow on the edges will be less than the average flow. That is true at the inlet, 1 foot in, and 10 feet in. If the cross-sectional area doesn't change, then the area-averaged velocity won't change either.

Please specify a jurisdiction. PEs have only been a thing in the US for about 100 years and legislation to establish them exists at the state level. These laws have been amended many, many times over the years and would have had different requirements for the initial roll out...

...but I think you may simply be misunderstanding the distinction between the "qualifying experience" requirement and the most common route to satisfying that requirement (i.e., working under another PE).

It used to be that certain people who worked in the field of engineering could be "grandfathered" as P.E.s if they got existing P.E.s to endorse their application to the state licensing board. These potential candidates would have to demonstrate that they had a certain number of years of experience in addition to the endorsements of other P.E.s. The "grandfather" route is no longer available, and AFAIK, all P.E. candidates must attend an accredited engineering school and take the EIT and FE exams to becomes licensed.

In the U.S., the first engineering licensure law was enacted in Wyoming in 1907. This article outlines some significant milestones in licensure since then: https://www.nspe.org/resources/press-room/resources/100-years-engineering-licensure

In the UK, the various Engineering Institutes (Mechanical, Electrical, etc) were originally learned societies. A group of like minded people (usually the leading figures in the industry) got together to found the society, write its rule-book, and appoint its first officers. New members would be proposed and seconded by existing members and approved or rejected by a vote, just like any other "private member's club". Setting up the modern system of "chartered engineers" (roughly equivalent to the USA PEs) happened much later, after the organizations had already existed for 100 years or more.

@Robotbugs That's correct: My design assumes a platform which holds the solenoid and claw, and moves forward and backwards.

@masiewpao - No, you can't redo the calculation for every slightly deformed structure, *because L in the equation is the undeformed length*. If you put on 0.1F, then the structure will deform delta1 = 0.1FL/(EA). If you then add another 0.1F, making the total 0.2F, the total elongation is delta1+delta2 = 0.2FL/(EA). It is not correct to say delta2 = 0.1F(L+delta1)/(EA), *because the delta=FL/(EA) formula is based on undeformed length L*.

That way lies madness. Obviously, delta = (FL) / (AE) has been verified for single cables being pulled, and there was no need to iterate a solution as long as the stress F/A remains in the elastic range of the material. If you go beyond the elastic limit, then you no longer have a linear problem to analyze, and an iterative approach may be required.

"That way lies madness." That is not true. There is nothing "mad" about formulating continuum mechanics using different stress and strain measures from the "engineering" small stress and strain used in most beginning courses. For example it is a big *advantage* (not "madness") to use stress and strain measures that are zero for large rigid body rotations - consider what happens to the cable if you pull it so that it rotates 90 degrees from its original direction. Of course if the *displacements* of the structure are "small", the differences between the various formulations are also small.

@AndyT You don't need to "redo the calculations for every slightly deformed structure". You just formulate the problem measuring strain in a different way. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deformation_(mechanics) for a summary of several different strain measures that are all used in real-world engineering. The fact that beginning courses in mechanics of materials only use *one* measure of stress and strain may give students the wrong idea that this is the *only* way to measure them.

Rules of thumb are dependent on context. For flow of water in a pipe generally, you are balancing the trade off of pressure loss and line size. Pressure loss = electricity usage where water is being pumped. Line size = capital costs and foot print of the plumbing. In this respect it's a tradeoff of operating vs. capital costs. To optimize these it depends on context: location, project goals, etc. If you want a rough estimate of what velocities are reasonable, [a set of tables like this is instructive](http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/pressure-loss-steel-pipes-d_307.html)

@Usagi, I don't think the concern when moving water around is cavitation. Vapor pressure of water at ambient temperature is around 0.02 atm. If the system is discharging to 1 atm, it's very unlikely to reach that sort of vacuum while still discharging the water. Also, I assume OP is talking about water velocity in a run of pipe (downstream of any pumps) so cavitation can't happen.

In short: Copute reactions (W/L*L*L/2 at each end), slice the beam at center and take moments of load and reactions in one side relative to the slicing point. Moment of reaction will be (W/L*L*L/2)*L/2 and moment of load -(W/L*L*L/2)*L/4 (please notice opposite signs). By summing and multiplying you get W/L*L^2/8. There are a lot of tutorials about moments in a simply supported beam, for instance http://bendingmomentdiagram.com/tutorials/how-to-find-bending-moment-diagrams/ or https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EPWBGqTfjwY

15N is a tiny force for a "real" longbow, but of course real longbows are not made from wimpy PVC pipe. The typical draw force of a modern longbow used for hunting animals is around 250N. As a military weapon used by professionally trained archers, the draw weights of 16th century longbows have been measured between about 450 and 800N, but those bows were about 2m long, not 1.2m. (Those guys were serious athletes - they could shoot several arrows per minute continuously with those draw weights!)

This is only true for continuous systems... For discrete systems, the stablility condition is such that the poles lie in the complex unit circle. This is because instead of ODE's, we get difference equations whose solutions have a factor of $\lambda^t$, where lambda is a pole. With this factor, solutions only blow up to infinity for large $t$ when a pole has magnitude greater than unity.

As long as there is no moment end release between the little beam and the column, then any vertical force at the main beam end of the little beam will cause a moment at the column end of the little beam, which will be transferred into the column. Also, if there is no torsion release in the main beam / moment release in the little beam, then that creates bending in the little beam, which will again be transferred into the column (assuming no moment release). This is basic statics.

@Graviton: Disagreeing with AndyT, the fictitious beam created to represent the offset is usually defined as infinitely stiff. This certifies that whatever deformations are imposed on one beam are adequately mirrored in the other. That being said, one shouldn't model infinitely stiff members as $EI=\infty$ (where $\infty$ is represented by an obscenely large number) since that can lead to numerical errors in your stiffness matrix. There are methods that adequately handle rigid members, but I'm not sure what they are.

@Graviton: If you're developing your own software, then implementing offset geometry (which imposes a relationship between the deformations of two separate nodes) is the best solution. That being said, I don't know how to do that either.

@Graviton "all of the stiffness terms in the corresponding row in the stiffness matrix must be set to 0" That looks wrong. You can't make a stiffness matrix unsymmetrical by just changing the terms in a *row*. The right way to do this is leave introduce a *new variable* for each "released" DOF. But since you are not usually interested in the value of that variable, in practice you *eliminate the released variable* from the element stiffness (which changes *all* the stiffness coefficients in the element) *before* you assemble the stiffness matrix for the complete structure.

@Chris: Assuming you didn't weigh that particular filter first, I guess I would first weigh a bunch of filters and hope their weight variation is within your desired margin of error, so you can subtract the filter weight. If there's still "sludge" then there is still liquid, so I would try to rinse that out with acetone (or another handy volatile grease solvent) until you're left only with powder once the cleaner evaporates. Once you're dealing with sludge this rinse can require some mechanical agitation to get the solvent to break things up without running a continuous rinse process.
Okay I will give it a try. Thank you.

@Chris - Another thought, if you don't need to be *too* precise, is that you could burn what's left and weigh it. To account for the filter ash, burn a plain filter and weigh its ash. At low enough temperature hopefully you won't add to the mass of the metal alloys through oxidization, and by now you will have reduced the oil and degreaser mass in your sample enough that their solid combustion products will fall within your desired margin of error.

Welded connections are usually simplified into hinged (moment release) connections. Correct, the resultant frequency measured at any one location will likely not instantaneously be at atomic clock tolerance. The measuring device wouldnt have that resolution anyways. The controlling system however does use the atomic clock as the time control reference, so within a period of time (1 minute, 1 hour, 1 day) the average frequency will be of this tolerance. This is why it is possible to run a low cost grid tied clock for a year and hold atomic clock tolerance. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utility_frequency#Time_error_correction_.28TEC.29

Re: "Some gearbox data and empirical motor current data would go a long way to predicting the performance." It is difficult to estimate operating torque from motor current for utility powered motor. It is extremely difficult for a VFD powered motor. It is better to use measured power for utility powered motors and, for VFD powered motors, VFD operating parameters (torque, percent load or DC bus current).

AB VFD parameter 024 is an internal torque command read-only display that is active only when the 053 Motor Cntl Sel is set to 4 FVC Vector. That is the higher performance encoderless vector control mode that requires the self tuning procedure to be performed with the motor. That control mode is also required to enable 436 Pos Torque Limit, the torque limit setting that is required for this application.

Re "No closed loop torque sensor will be used as they are prohibitively expensive." That is no surprise. However, to get the 2% regulation requires only a motor shaft encoder. That is much less expensive, but a substantial addition to the motor cost plus the cost of a special cable in a separate conduit from the motor. The encoder allows torque calculation using motor slip calculated from frequency and speed and/or torque angle calculated from rotor position and the vector value of motor current.

@Graviton you may have to go back to study some beginners statics to be prepared to at least comprehend the basics of joint constrains. It is assumed that the questioner has the minimum knowledge to be familiar with the basic ideas. Here is just a few examples of joint release: Total release, removal of support. Moment release, joint is pin connected. Shear release, the joint is on rollers in the direction where moment is allowed, like a drawer on rollers which can't tip over. torsion release means member can roll at joint but is constrained otherwise. Like a car antenna's base connection.

So your question is, "What options exist to model the effects of stress on metal parts?"

@massey95: Yes, the average shear stress times the cross-sectional area equals the applied force. This can be understood by Newton's Third Law: the internal stress state in the beam is created to withstand the external force, so the total internal force must be equal to the external force. If it were different (greater or lesser), then the system wouldn't be in equilibrium. Since the internal force is found by $V_I = \int_A \tau\text{d}A \equiv \overline\tau A = V_E$.

@massey95: This also answers your second question. External loads generate internal stresses along the beam. These stresses can be integrated along the entire area to obtain equivalent internal forces. As the integral states, $V_{int} = \int_A \tau\text{d}A$. For any given point $\text{d}A=0 \therefore V_{int}=0$ for that point. The entire concept of internal force requires one to look at a larger scale than any single point. If you're looking at the section as a whole (or large part), then forces make sense. If you're looking at a point, then only stresses make sense.

The problem with buckling is that it's very sensitive to the direction of the force applied at the ends of the beam. That can play a large part in the buckling *mode*, which determines the shape the beam makes when it fails - a 'C' or an 'S', etc. Like with a nil ductility test or similar, the only way you can guarantee to instrument the correct location for buckling is to intentionally create a defect that ensures the buckling mode.

Not quite sure what you're asking. "Is it possible to have a container such that if you fill it with helium it is less dense than air?" - Yes, see balloons. "Is it possible for a tank full of helium not to lift, but when you pump the helium out of that tank into an attached balloon, for that balloon to then lift the tank?" - No, the lift of the helium when in the balloon is the same as when it was in the tank (ignoring the small increase in volume of the balloon and hence decrease in density).

If you regulate speed, the torque transmitted to the load will be whatever it takes to drive the load at the speed you select. If the drive doesn't have the capability to produce enough torque to drive the load at the selected speed, regulation will fail and the drive will either operate at a lower speed than selected or malfunction in some manner. The torque vs speed capability of the drive will vary according to the specific technology selected.

"ANY non-zero torque would be sufficient" - the only forces will be air resistance, friction in the bearings, etc, and those forces will be small at only 5 RPM. A more relevant question might be "how quickly do you want to *accelerate* the rotor from rest to 5 RPM". That will depend on the moment of inertia of the rotor about the axis and the acceleration required.
As stated by @alephzero, what we need is the acceleration desired to reach from zero to 5 RPM. Or, equivalently, the time necessary to accelerate to the desired speed.

Oh, one final comment about the "as seen by the thing you care about" proviso - You said the windmill is "connected to the motor" - if this is the case, then no problem. If the windmill is connected *to a gearbox* that is connected to the motor, then you need to take that into account. Speed is transformed by the gearbox ratio, but [inertia is changed by the **square** of the gearbox ratio](https://www.physicsforums.com/threads/inertia-change-through-a-gearbox-question.387779/). Rotor inertia of a motor/generator is usually very significant.

@chris360 - Generally speaking, when you post a question like this, you should write down all the steps *you* took in trying to solve the problem, with an English description of what you're attempting to accomplish with each step. You should actually do this for all your work - future homework, tests, research projects, theses, software - English comments are a lifesaver when you go back weeks or years later and try to figure out what you were doing.

Anyways, you might find that [you solve your own problem in just writing the description of the problem and what you tried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubber_duck_debugging). I've solved my own problems like this, posting here and subsequently deleting the question before it was asked, dozens of times, sometimes on extraordinarily difficult projects I've been working on for months.

The torque capability of the drive setup will be determined by the characteristics of the CVT and whatever is driving the CVT. To some extent, the best choice of CVF technology will depend on the torque vs speed capability characteristics of whatever is driving the CVT. With the proper choice of CVT, you can get increased torque capability with increased input speed.

Are you given the coordinates for the end location? Without some means for closed-loop control, you're forced to rely on open-loop control. Even if you could put encoders on the wheels and get PID steering, you need some *reference* with which to feed the PID controller. If you can't localize yourself relative to the objective then there isn't anything you can do. As you said yourself, "How will I line the car up perfectly straight?" The answer is - you won't. Closed loop control or bust - there's nothing else you can do. Can you ID the target with a camera and do visual tracking?

Curious to know. What kind of force would be induced or deducted from that would cause more inefficiencies in cars with piezoelectricity?

The piezoelectric effect is that a voltage is caused due to stresses in the material. That requires that the material moves slightly, unless it has an infinite youngs modulus it must move when under stress. In other words the car has to push the road down a tiny amount. If the road the car is on is pressed down and the road in front of it isn't then the car is effectively constantly driving uphill.
Oh I see. So there isn't much practicality with cars.
Just to be clear, piezoelectricity is generated by *strain*. Strain is the motion that is caused by stress (force).

mg4w gives a good answer. Nitro-glycerine based explosives, old fashioned dynamite & gelignite could be sensitive to small shocks & needed to be treated with respect, particularly if the explosive was "sweating": beads of nitro-glycerine collecting on the surface of the explosive. When it comes to explosives, the rule is be gentle with them & treat them with respect.

No, it's usually an electrical switch that controls the power to the compressor. If the temperature is too high, run the compressor; it it's low enough, turn off the compressor. Generally, the temperature-sensitive switch (a.k.a. "thermostat") has a certain amount of hysteresis so that the on-off cycles do not occur too frequently.

@Graviton - No, that's not what I'm saying. There is a difference between what you tell the analysis, and what the analysis tells you. If you tell the analysis that there is no moment at the column joint, then you need to make sure in your detailing of the joint that it cannot transmit moment. If you tell the analysis that there *can* be moment at the joint, and the analysis tells you that there is no moment occurring you a) think your analysis package is broken; but if you check the results and are happy with them then b) you can detail the joint however you like (as long as it meets code).

@Graviton - I stand by my answer, except if you like you can substitute "Your engineering friend" for "You". If you detail the joint such that no moment can be transferred from the beam to the column then no moment can be transferred from the beam to the column. @Graviton: Exactly. For there to be a discontinuity in the bending moment diagram, a concentrated moment must be applied at the point of the discontinuity. They may be an external force applied at the point or, in the case of a grid structure (as opposed to frame structures as you're currently designing), torsion and bending moments can "transform" from one to the other when perpendicular beams are connected.

@Graviton - Right, I've been thinking about this. I think it fitted best in [my answer to the other question](http://engineering.stackexchange.com/a/11127/255) so I've put it formally there. I think your friend is designing as pin-ended because he thinks it's safer: a failed continuous beam may then act as a pin-ended beam (if there is rotational capacity). But he is then thinking "well, the detailing at the joints is for continuous, I'd better make sure it is also able to act continuously". {cont}

@Graviton: As to your second comment, I don't understand what you mean. As AndyT mentions in his answer, your reinforcement and your analysis must be compatible. If your beam is hinged, then the reinforcement must be adequate for a hinged connection (which implies in no principle reinforcement continuity between beam and column). If the beam is fixed, then there must be significant reinforcement continuity.
{cont} Rather than use an empirical method to give the moment in the joint, the analysis should be re-run using fix-ended beams.

@Graviton: If you look at the examples of different hinges I showed in [an answer to a previous question of yours](http://engineering.stackexchange.com/a/8918/1832), you'll notice that it is impossible to have any significant reinforcement continuity. Freysinnet hinges have no reinforcement at all, while other hinges have specific reinforcement for the hinge but the majority of the beam and column reinforcement are terminated at the hinge. A fixed node, however, wouldn't have the narrow throat, but would be a monolithic connection with almost all the column and beam rebar passing through.

Could you please [edit] your question with a drawing/sketch of the connection you're asking about (including reinforcement)? This has become very generic and theoretical, while your question seems to be far more down-to-earth.

+1, but I'd add that many engineers I've worked with (and I agree with them) prefer to put all the dimensions which might be useful, even if some of them end up being "redundant". This limits the risk of accidental arithmetic mistakes. So long as you don't take it to the extreme and the drawing becomes cluttered, the more information, the better.

Just to spell out some of the reasons if they are not "obvious": There are many ways to reproduce drawings on paper (or computer displays) that don't maintain 1:1 scale, and many consumer-quality photocopiers and printers don't have exactly the same scaling in the X and Y directions. Even if you avoid those problems, "ordinary paper" isn't dimensionally stable, and it changes size by different amounts along and across the "grain" of the paper as the humidity changes.

Adding to @Wasabi's comment, redundant dimensions are often labelled differently from other dimensions, for example I've seen "reference dimensions" surrounded by parentheses like so: (100). It's important to indicate which dimensions should be prioritized/must be exact during construction and which ones are there for reference, especially when you are indicating things like machining tolerances

@Graviton: To quote AndyT's answer, "The key point you seem to be missing is that one must reflect the other". It is utterly nonsensical to analyze the structure one way and design it another. One must choose. If the structure is to be pinned, it must be analyzed and designed accordingly. Likewise if it should be fixed. The only exception is in the paranoid case suggested by [AndyT's other answer](http://engineering.stackexchange.com/a/11127/255), where the structure is continuous and then you analyze and design it as BOTH pinned and fixed.

I'm not sure if you're asking whether anyone would simply measure out on the drawing and then apply the reverse scale to get any necessary dimension, but if you are, then in almost all cases the answer would be "no". The only time a scale drawing might be measured that I'm aware of is when it's a map or floor plan, and in the latter case that would never be done for actual construction. A contractor might measure a drawing and apply the reverse scale to estimate lengths of cable, conduit, or pipe needed for a job. That's the only real world case I've seen.

If this is a "full size" vehicle (not something like an RC model), since the OP is in the UK there could be some serious legal issues involved if the modified vehicle was ever going to be used on public roads - for example, how to keep the modified vehicle compliant with the MOT (safety test) regulations for traction control and ABS brakes, and whether an insurance company would provide cover for it.

@Nixt - The torque applied to the wheel by the engine does not change with wheel diameter. What *does* change is the force that the wheel applies to the ground. Torque is $\tau = FL$ for a wheel in contact with the ground (perpendicular contact). That is, the force you get out is $F = \tau/L$. Convert your wheel *diameters* in inches to the equivalent *radii* in feet: (11.5/2)*(1/12) = 0.479ft, 0.854ft for the other. For the first scenario, $10ftlb/0.479ft = 21lb$ of force. For the second, $19.97/0.854 = 23.4lb$ of force.

So, the new gear ratio helped, but doubling the torque *and* almost doubling the tire diameter means that you're left with basically the same amount of force at the pavement, so you won't notice *any* performance gains. The acceleration when you start is dictated by $F=ma$, which can be restated as $a=F/m$. So, if you lower the mass you can increase acceleration, or if you raise the force you can increase acceleration. I'll warn that any gains you get in low-end acceleration come out of top-end speed. If you keep a low gearing (+torque) and small tire, you accelerate faster to a lower speed.

You have some ambiguity between power output and rated speed. For the matter of getting a motor of higher rated speed your interpretation is pretty good, but the case of getting a motor with more torque but the same nameplate speed is missing. Oversizing is also usually done through a getting more torque, as additional speed means pretty much nothing except for specific loads. Catalogs usually list a specific speed as the fixed feature and then present variations with different torque.

@WalyKu if you are picking a motor itself, that's a fair distinction. If you're picking a gearmotor or you have control over your gearing then you can balance torque vs speed as needed in the gear ratio. In my world at least, you usually pick a motor and gearing at the same time.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_transmission#Parts_and_operation has a general introduction. For more detail, try searching for the brand names of early automatic transmission designs, e.g. Hydramatic, Hy-drive, Dynaflow, Powerglide, etc.

Actually, AIUI, a turbocharger does little to nothing to improve the efficiency of any particular *engine*. The main thing it does is enable you to get higher peak power out of a given displacement. However, this allows you to increase the overall efficiency of a *vehicle* by allowing you to put a smaller, lighter engine in the vehicle without sacrificing peak performance.

This is a [statically indeterminate truss](http://www.ae.msstate.edu/vlsm/truss/statically_det_indet_trusses/statically_det_indet_trusses.htm). You cannot solve for the reactions simply by summing moments. For a truss to be solvable from equilibrium alone it must satisfy the following equation: $m + r \leq 2j$. Where m is the number of members (7), r is the number of reactions (6 - 2 per support how you have drawn it), and j is the number of joints (5). Therefore we have: $7 + 6 \nless 2(5)$. You will need to use another method, such as the Force Method to solve this.

I think the more common term for this quantity is *specific weight*. It is not an "imperial unit system" quantity, but an engineering quantity. It can be expressed as force per unit volume, which can be expressed in any unit system, including the metric system. You should read the wikipedia page on its uses: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specific_weight

They're two sides of the same coin. Z-transform is the discrete version of the Laplace transform. I would say it's generally easiest to do all of your work in the continuous-time domain and later, when you've got a controller that simulates well, convert from continuous time to discrete time by applying the Z-transform anywhere you see an 's'. I'd say this is similar to algebra - do you substitute the numbers in the beginning or in the end? Either way you should end with the same answer, but by substituting from the start you lose both conceptual understanding and ease of later substitutions.

At the PhD level (and largely also at the master's level), the subject of the degree is mostly just a name; your real expertise will be given more by the classes you take and the research you do. Along the same lines, the research you do will be dictated more by what your committee chair wants to do than what you want to do. This is generally the reason people would change universities for a master's or PhD - to find a professor whose research aligns with their interests. This way you get to work with someone who wants you to do what you want to do.

So, then really everything depends on what *you* want to do. You should work with the professor whose research aligns with your interests. Maybe the professor at your university most aligned with your interest is a physicist. In that case, consider a physics degree; vice-versa for engineering. Again, the coursework and research really tells what you did, not so much the title. But I think what @CarlWitthoft was getting at is that it depends on what **you** want to do, and nobody here knows you. Your advisors should know you, which is why you should contact them first.

I went to a university with 30,000 people - my advisor knew me by name, knew my interests, and was the one that first introduced me to the professor that became my master's committee chair and primary research advisor. Regarding your question - engineering is applying science to real problems. If you're interested in real-world applications, study engineering. Physicists generally are interested in explaining real-world observations. If you're interested in the theoretical, study physics. Experimental physicists try to prove the theoretical physics.

Solidworks automatic fully define sketch feature is very "dumb", and using it is a lazy approach. it generally just adds lots and lots of dimensions which can destroy the intent of the sketch/make changes very difficult. In steel, austenite only changes to martensite directly if cooling occurs rapidly enough (before sufficient diffusion of carbon to allow nucleation of ferrite). The transformation temperatures are usually significantly lower than 727C. Consider this [AISI 4340 IT diagram](https://www.rose-hulman.edu/~stienstr/me%20328/2005Exam4_files/image002.jpg) which has the Martensite Start temperature closer to 290C. Not shown, but AISI 1095 is near 425C. 727C is the A1 temperature at which austenite and ferrite exchange stability.

@Montag451 Front is a label - with a car (like a ship or a plane), "front" and "forward" are assumed to be the way the driver/helmsman/pilot is facing during vehicle operation. This is the thing that's up to you to decide for your labeling system. Again, I might argue that, *if you were* on *the machine*, then you would naturally face the operator. This means the operator and the machine are standing "nose to nose". In this case, like I mention above, machine forward is close to the operator, aft is away, port is operator right, stbd is operator left.

Yes, I know it and I want to learn the term which defines this "viewpoint reference" clearly and with one and a single word group. Something like "driver's orientation" etc. This was the closest thing that we could come up with and even it isn't right on the spot because most of the time we have to explain ourselves by what we mean with it.

@Montag451 - I think with any machine that doesn't have an operator cab, you'll always have to define the coordinates up front. But using internationally-recognized color codes would help remind people what the orientation is.

On the other hand, I attended a seminar on durability of concrete and it was mentioned there that the modulus of elasticity of concrete is different at the top of a slab, compared to the bottom. Just a minor pedantic point that has always irritated me about these brain teaser questions: if the ramp is truly frictionless, the items will not roll. They'll all slide at the same acceleration. (I'm happy to be corrected if anyone thinks I'm wrong though.)

Just an idea - you might like to look at "syncro drive" used on some mobile robots. Some of these use chain or belt drive for transmission to of all of the wheels, though I think at lower speeds. (There's also a second chain used for steering.)

Can you elaborate a little more with regard to the quality of water / air you wish to purify? You need to have to know exactly what contaminants you wish to remove to specify an economical way of removing them. An example would be suspended solid matter in water (or dust in air).
